Good thread. TLDR: one commandment is an oversimplification, but a useful oversimplification.

One way to think about it: when you pitch your community to a new recruit, how do you describe it?

Culdesac: car-free
Kift: van life
Praxis: vitalist

Note what this is *not*. It's not an economic pitch. It's a values pitch.

The first failure mode is just doing a vanilla tech company. This presumes a values neutrality that no longer exists.

The second is to do a tech community, but without articulating what values you stand for — or to do a DAO that's just pure economics ("wen airdrop").

The one commandment pushes back on both of these

Your thread is good, but I think of it as addressing the third order failure mode, which is doing a tech community and then focusing TOO much on a very explicit, non-economic core value.

But the problem with today's startup societies is not an excess of focus on non-economic community values. It's the opposite.

To elaborate a little, why is doing a vanilla tech company non-ideal in 2023?

Because we don't live in the states of 2003, we live in the networks of 2023. You aren't interacting with your geographical neighbors, but with your network neighbors.

Ah, but WHO are your network neighbors? That's where values come in.

Good thread by  on one commandment

TLDR: he's right but in a 3rd order way
Most startups aren't societies
And most societies don't have *too much* moral focus
farcaster://casts/0x3845716175dbe9ba157abf49b1d125910596b13983b237982c0419a8eefb0967/0x3845716175dbe9ba157abf49b1d125910596b13983b237982c0419a8eefb0967

And on the 2nd failure mode...why do people do tech communities rather than tech companies, but focus on economics solely and not values?

Because economics is easy! As per Idiocracy, "you like money? wow, me too!"

Everyone likes money. But money runs out.
Values polarize. Scary! But are still there in a market crash

So, how do we compactly tell people to (a) do a tech community rather than a tech company and (b) to articulate a set of values for that community rather than the purely economic — values that give a reason for the community to exist in a bear market other than "wen airdrop"?

That's the purpose of the one commandmen

There's a lot of history that I've compacted down into this section, but in short: communities with non-economic reasons to succeed often beat those that are purely economic.

The Puritans were zealots, while purely for-profit colonies didn't make it through the winters.
https://thenetworkstate.com/the-one-commandment

That said, most people haven't thought explicitly about values, and are loath to preach their "religion" (though often eager to evangelize their politics!)

In between the reticence to religiously evangelize and the zeal to politically evangelize — between 0 and infinity — I recommend one (1) explicit commandment.

Once people have thought through that one explicit commandment — perhaps it's Praxis's "vitalism is good" or Culdesac's "car free is good" or Kift's "van life is good", there's much they can do beyond that.

They can layer on explicit 2nd commandments, or all manner of implicit/illegible things as  points out.

The reason to just do "one" commandment is the same reason you just do one product as a startup. One is already a lot! It's essentially working through how every aspect of society changes in response to a moral innovation.

The dietary ones are the easiest to see: veganism or carnivory both change every single meal.

Yes: you can add 2nd commandments, and of course illegible bits too

But without being able to explicitly articulate *some* reason why your community must exist, why it morally improves on the mainstream…you'll eventually succumb to the mainstream, which has N very explicit commandments! https://i.imgur.com/vtW0nIh.p

TLDR

If you don't have explicit values, you'll lose to those that do.

Consider the sign with N explicit establishment commandments & the responses. Some are funny! Yet by referencing the original, all operate implicitly within its frame.

A strong one commandment can break that frame.
 https://i.imgur.com/yxPNPYF.jpg

Yes.

Personnel > policy is often true.

On the other hand, explicit > implicit valuable to prevent absorption.

The US Constitution's explicitly stated negative rights are a good example of where explicit > implicit.

A startup is a company, a society is a community.

A startup is selling a product to an individual (or a small business, or a big company). It's an economic transaction.

A society is evangelizing a way of life to an individual (or a family, or a subcommunity). It's social membership.

For most companies, there isn't a network effect. Each buyer transacts independent of other buyers. Your purchase of a chair doesn't really depend on others.

Recently, tech companies have blurred the difference with network effects. Others do matter.

But for tech communities, the network is the *primary* thing.

A tech company wants to sell something.
A tech community stands for something.

Yes, I actually agree a one commandment is indeed an oversimplification — but a useful one! Because many (most?) startup communities can't explain why they exist. More:

Crypto is about digital property rights and digital human rights. It’s about protecting your money, your thoughts, and your accounts from malicious corporations and governments alike.

The need for that will only grow. And that’s why I’m committed to the space.

Bezos talks about betting on constants, not variables.

People may not always want Beanie Babies, but they’ll always want lower prices. So Amazon focused on that.

Similarly, people may not always want any given NFT, but they will always want control over their assets and their accounts. So we focus on that.

The counterargument is that “most people don’t want the hassle of self custody.”

The counter-counterargument is that even if only the population of GitHub *does* want self custody — even if only tens of millions of power users demand it — that is enough to keep corporations and governments honest.

Moreover, the UX of self custody keeps improving with companies like Casa and tools for social reset.

And Apple’s recent rollout of Advanced Data Protection is educating millions about the utility of crypto-like recovery keys.

Since time immemorial, bankrupt states (and their unfortunate citizens) have had a desperate appetite for hard currency.

Historically, that’s meant gold, or stable foreign fiat. If cryptocurrency is auditioning for that role, it’s going to need to prove itself truly seizure-resistant.

That means OS resistance.

That doesn’t actually help that much, because if the private key is ever present on the device (such as when sending a transaction), it can be scraped by a malicious OS and your wallet drained.

(There are workarounds like never fully putting the key together and only broadcasting signed transactions. Not that easy.)

Yes, we need something like ethOS, Solana phone, or Qubes. Maybe an Urbit box.

An ultra secure operating system for desktop & mobile dedicated to crypto.

We also need to move enough funds on there in a relatively short time to make seizure unattractive.

This is hard for anything but an Android fork, and even then...

Perhaps it was always so, but for several years now it’s felt like the collective consciousness has extreme presentism.

Imagine each NFT community had a group of mods. And when those mods like your post, you get a custom NFT.

Now each community can optimize a different metric besides popularity!

For example, in a proof-of-workout community you must post workout selfies to earn workout credit NFTs.

Other ideas for useful NFT communities

1) proof-of-skill: complete a technical exam in a given area to earn a proof-of-skill NFT.

2) proof-of-diet: post videos of eating healthy food to earn NFTs & get social reinforcement.

In each case moderators review the submissions, maintain the leaderboard, and award the NFTs.

The fundamental shift is from spending millions on one NFT to sending millions of NFTs for one dollar.

This is now easy on Solana with compressed NFTs but may be feasible on Ethereum too.

An NFT is then a collectible — a free little digital tchotke, similar to a like. People earn & award billions of them each day.

Yes. It makes communities useful. You aren’t just there to hang out with people with PFPs. You are optimizing a long term metric that’s valuable to you.

Self improvement communities. Directional, unlike the entropy of social media. Compounding interest every day.

Yes, that’s a crucial distinction that even many ostensible patriots don’t get.

The Soviet Union had a useful distinction between the Soviet and the Russian. When the Soviet Empire fell, the Russian still existed.

Soviets were proud of Stalin and the empire. But Russians were proud of Pushkin and Mendeleev.

The 20th century political spectrum was from left to right: communist, socialist, capitalist, nationalist.

The 21st century political spectrum may be from bottom-up to top-down: maximalist, decentralist, statist, militarist.

Bitcoin Maximalists are not fully ideologically consistent, but are close to anarcho-capitalists in their antipathy to state control.

Decentralists would mean Ethereans and most of the people on Farcaster.

Maximalist is to Decentralist roughly as Communist is to Socialist. The more intense version…

We don’t have great words for the centralist side of the 21st century spectrum, but I picked statist and militarist.

The left statist wants regulation, the right statist wants tariffs, but both want state control over the economy — and oppose decentralists and maximalists.

The militarist wants war on top of that.

The problem with America First is that 96% of the world is not American.

America First is fundamentally incompatible with the US as the credibly neutral referee of the “rules-based order”. It says the US will bend the rules to benefit itself.

So what happens then? Others want France First, Turkey First, etc.

Paradoxically, as the rules-based order breaks down, the empire that many confused nationalists are proud of also breaks down with it.

It’s like tech platforms. If Oracle is too aggressively “Oracle first”,  if it’s not neutral, then people move to neutral Postgres.

“America first” results in America last

What you want instead is enlightened self interest. If you’re maintaining a platform, you can’t take too much for yourself and sometimes you need to let the rules bind you too.

Fintech on frontend: build modern user interfaces to these systems so you don’t need to keep re-entering data.

Blockchain on backend: large online communities establish crypto passport reciprocality.

That is — the entire area of passports, residency, travel, immigration, visas, identity, etc is a regulated mess.

But so was currency.

If you could get cryptopassport reciprocity between large online communities like Ethereum and Solana, like an ENS/SNS bridge, that’s a new model for diplomatic relations.

Reconceptualizing login reciprocity as passport reciprocity is useful.

For example, you can log in to MySpace nowadays with Facebook but not vice versa.

Being able to log in to GitHub with ENS — or otherwise bridge web2 and web3 credentials — is the seed of a different kind of immigration system.

Blockchains are most useful as a tool to innovate in regulated industries. 

You build a parallel state onchain that subsumes the function of the agency you are competing with.

Legitimacy comes from millions democratically opting into the new system. Capital to defeat the old system comes from asset appreciation.

In this model, Bitcoin competes with the Fed and Ethereum competes with the SEC.

This is *different* from the mid-2000s era startup playbook, which assumes your competitors are companies.

The new playbook recognizes that the primary obstacles are DC-affiliated actors around the world. New tactics are thus needed.

Examples:

- Fed → digital gold
- SEC → onchain issuance
- Harvard → onchain credentials
- Passports → onchain identity
- Newspapers → cryptographically verifiable truth
- Regulators → onchain digitally signed reviews and bans from online marketplaces

Decentralization is abstract.

Who is in control of a digital system?
Can someone delete you?

Why is decentralization important?
Because control is important.

Who is in charge
Who has root access
Who is the system administrator
Who has the final say

These aren’t just abstract technical questions, they are concrete political questions.

This is why crypto is inherently political.

It takes the endless, eternal human question — who is in charge? — and expresses it in code and puts it on the internet.

Who is in charge is an intrinsically political question, even if the answer is “no one”.

Yes, we can layer apolitical use cases on top of a blockchain’s base political assumptions.

But these are apolitical in the sense that driving to McDonald’s is apolitical.

Why is the road there? Why is capitalism even legal? Those were political decisions that set platform rules. Then we do things on top of that.

There is another view, that crypto reduces or eliminates the need for politics.

This is also true if you define politics as electoral power struggles. It’s taking things out of that arena.

But doing that is itself meta-political.

But the counter-counterargument is that if you (a) had those hashes digitally signed, (b) had months or years of hashes consistently uploaded, and (c) had multiple oracles all paying to write the same hashes, it becomes harder to fake.

d) There is a nontrivial transaction cost to continuously writing 144 hashes per day to the Bitcoin chain, which deters causal griefing.

e) The hashes will themselves be referenced via social media commentary, generating more backlinks.

f) Hashes can be compared against claimed archives of the Ethereum chain.

I say “claimed” archives in the last point because in a true hall-of-mirrors situation many people might claim to have an archive of the full Ethereum chain.

Long-term stability is unusual.

It’s absolutely imperative to keep this in mind or else you are shooting the messenger.

Fourth, technological disruption is the *opposite* of political stability.

The future isn’t exactly like the present, just with nicer gadgets. Was the 20th century just the same kings, except in royal cars?

No. Because old political institutions weren’t set up to deal with new technologies. Many didn’t survive.

Why is it better?

Because blockchains are digital governments.

They *replace* traditional governments for those functions.

That is why improvement in a regulated industry like finance has even become possible.

Once you understand that blockchains are digital governments, that they are a quiet global political revolution, and that they allow millions to opt out of bad states & into good networks…you have 3 choices.

You can get it.
You can not get it.
Or you can pretend to not get it.

All three are actually useful. Why?

If you get it, you’re proceeding eyes wide open. That’s why Satoshi was pseudonymous — he knew the impact of what he was doing, and that the state would try to shut down his new network if successful.

This is Neo level. It’s cliche but you see the Matrix.

If you don’t get it, but hold crypto, or build things on the APIs without realizing why they exist…that’s actually still useful.

This is normie level.

It’s like being a user of software. You don’t get how it all works under the hood. But you don’t need to, either. You just see that it’s useful to you.

Jacob’s proposal is a great idea because it signals who is both public-spirited AND technical enough to run a hub.

Such a person may be a good target for future airdrops — by you or by others!

In a sense, Jacob’s proposal turns running a hub into something similar to very early Bitcoin mining.

“Run this code to support a network. In return you get this currently worthless digital asset. But you may be rewarded some day of the network gets big.”

Note that the reward / airdrops may come from others.

This may be the right way to bootstrap a network with digital assets.

Not by issuing a token which is instantly liquid. That just attracts short-term ppl.

But by issuing “sweat NFTs”: a non-transferable NFT which *may* be a target for future airdrops, if the network works, but no promise of that.

NFT mining!

Some thoughts.

First, what he calls “programmable hardness” I’ve called “programmable scarcity”, as distinct from “programmable information.”

That is, the internet lets you *copy* digital objects easily, but blockchains let you also *transfer* them — by using cryptography to create digital scarcity.

However, “programmable hardness” may be a better phrase. It combines several concepts under one umbrella:

- financially hard, as in hard money 
- computationally hard, as in NP-hard
- legally hard, as in hard commitment 
- practically hard, as in hard to fake

And the visual is “physically hard” as in gold.

Programmable hardness is a generalization of the hard money that is Bitcoin. It pulls in many adjacent words:

- scarcity
- difficulty
- constraint 
- commitment
- immutable
- uncensorable
- fixed
- permanent
- archival
- reliable
- constant
- dependable
- trustworthy
- transparent
- provable
- verifiable

His word “cast” is also well chosen, as it relates the physical aspect of hardness to the temporal aspect of future reliability.

- trust the forecast
- cast it in stone
- and cast that stone into the future 

Also, cast as in “cast a vote” (a binding commitment) and “cast a shadow” (a line extending out).

Lol, and also “cast” as in Farcaster!! 🤪

I didn’t even realize that till just now.  did you pick the name with that connotation?

Farcaster: cast a commitment far into the future, like the blockchain.

His analogy between information theory and cryptographic hardness is also excellent.

Of course many have written on this topic, but quantifying the computational *and* financial cost of falsifying something may become as important as calculating how many bits it has.

“Hards” as the new bits?

Finally, the relationship between physical hardness (atoms), social hardness (institutions), and digital hardness (blockchains) is something I’ve also thought about.

Technology reduces scarcity, which means more food. But in doing so it also often erodes institutional certainty, which means more fights.

One answer is to use the hardness of math (cryptography) to restore the hardness of social institutions with blockchains.

Bitcoin difficulty is measured by how many hashes you need to solve the next block.

Hashes may be the units of hardness, like bits are the units of information.

Hashes also have a market rate, which can be expressed in USD…or in ounces of gold or BTC itself.

So: hashes measure computational + financial hardness.

A related concept is 33 bits for measuring privacy and anonymity.

2^33 = 8 billion 
And there are about 7 billion humans.
So with 33 bits of information you can figure out which human it is.

Anyway, with information we are now accustomed to talking about it. How many gigabytes is that file? All information is measured in bits.

Can we measure everything in crypto in hashes? Like: how many hashes would it take to falsify that? What’s it’s hardness? Perhaps this is too simple.

Yeah. I think it’s better to call them physical hardness, social hardness, and digital hardness.

There’s memorable assonance there. And digital is intermediate between physical and social while also being its own thing.
